, &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vespasian in his last\nletter to his son Titus, confesses that they are what they are solely owing to\nthe good advice of Apollonius (v 30).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Eunapius, the pupil of\nChrysanthius, one of the teachers of Emperor Julian, writing in the last years\nof the fourth century says that Apollonius was more than a philosopher; he was\n\u201ca middle term, as it were, between gods and men\u201d &nbsp;&nbsp;(&nbsp; IN\nINDIA WE CALL THEM 12 STRAND DNA, NIL JUNK MAHARISHIS )<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Damisa writes about his\ntravel with Apollonius to worship Mount Kailash, the pineal gland of the planet &nbsp;\u201c&nbsp;\nthey came in sight of the giant mountains, the Imaus (Himavat) where was\nthe great mountain Meros \u201c &nbsp; . He wrote that Apllonius was a physician of the SOUL.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-lGgrN8hYvTE/VxET8PwJQVI/AAAAAAABHls/YRJM0mSoaHQd1J766yvuz4dTGjt1B3uTwCLcB/s1600/pic-pcilgrims-at-kailash.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"358\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-lGgrN8hYvTE/VxET8PwJQVI/AAAAAAABHls/YRJM0mSoaHQd1J766yvuz4dTGjt1B3uTwCLcB/s640/pic-pcilgrims-at-kailash.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cApollonius in his\naddress to the Gymnosphists, Pythagoras was not the inventor of it. It was the\nimmemorial wisdom,&nbsp; and Pythagoras\nhimself had learnt it from the Indians.. \u201c<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cHis manner was ever\nmild and gentle (i 36; ii 22) and modest (iv 31; viii 15), and in this,says\nDamis,he was more like an Indian than a Greek (iii. Apollonius was a citizen of\nthe world, if there has ever been one, into whose speech the word native-land\ndid not enter, and a priest of universal religion in whose vocabulary the word\nsect did not exist.In spite of his extremely ascetic life he was a man of\nstrong physique, so that even when he has reached the ripe age of four-score\nyears, we are told, he was sound and healthy in every limb and organ, upright\nand perfectly formed.\u201d <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cBut Apollonius\ndeclared it brings us nearer to the real, as Pythagoras and Plato both who\nstudied in India declared before him, and as all the wiser teach. He meant this\nliterally, not vaguely and fantastically\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cApollonius seems to\nhave written many letters to emperors, kings, philosophers, communities and\nstates, although he was by no means a \u201cvoluminous correspondent\u201d; in fact, the\nstyle of his short notes is exceedingly concise\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cWriting to the priests\nof Delphi against the practice of blood-sacrifice, he says:27. \u201cHeraclitus was\na sage, but even he [That is to say, a philosopher of 600 years ago.] never\nadvised the people of Ephesus to wash out mud with mud.\u201d <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cBut besides these\nletters Apollonius also wrote a number of treatises, of which , however,only\none or two fragments have been preserved.These treatises are as follows:&nbsp; a. The Mystic Rites or Concerning Sacrifices.\n[The full title is given by Eudocia, Ionia; ed. Villoison (Venet 1781) p 57]\nThis treatise is mentioned by Philostratus (iii 41; iv 19), who tells us that\nit set down the proper method of sacrifice ( no blood ) to every God, the\nproper hours of prayer and offering. It was in wide circulation, and\nPhilostratus had come across copies of it in many temples and cities, and in\nthe libraries of philosophers. Several fragments of it have been preserved \u201c<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cThe pagan temples,\nmentioned by Philostratus, which Apollonius visited in Greece, have all the\npeculiarity of being very ancient;&nbsp; for\ninstance, Dodona, Dephi, the ancient shrine of Apollo at Ab\u00e6 in Phocis, the\n\u201ccaves\u201d of Amphiaraus [A great centre of divination by means of dreams (see ii\n37).] and Trophonius, and the temple of the Muses on Helicon\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cHis main external\nwork, however, was the giving of instruction, and, as Philostratus rhetorically\nphrases it, \u201cbowls of his words were set up everywhere for the thirsty to drink\nfrom\u201d (iv 24)\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">On his return to Greece\nby way of Africa and Sicily (where he spent some time and visited \u00c6tna), he\npassed the winter (? of 67 A.D.) at Eleusis, living in the temple, and in the\nspring of the following year sailed for Alexandria, spending some time on the\nway at Rhodes. The city of philosophy and eclecticism par excellence received\nhim with open arms as an old friend. But to reform the public cults of Egypt\nwas a far more difficult task than any he had previously attempted. His\npresence in the temple (? the temple of Serapis) commanded universal respect,\neverything about him and every world he uttered seemed to breathe an atmosphere\nof wisdom and of \u201csomething divine.\u201d The high priest of the temple looked on in\nproud disdain. \u201cWho is wise enough,\u201d he mockingly asked, \u201cto reform the\nreligion of the Egyptians?\u2014only to be met with the confident retort of\nApollonius: \u201cAny sage who comes from the Indian because we made it \u201c<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201c Here as elsewhere\nApollonius set his face against blood-sacrifice, and tried to substitute\ninstead, as he had attempted elsewhere, the offering of frankincense modeled or\nclarified butter in the form of the victim \u201c<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cThe most interesting\npart of Apollonius\u2019 work was of so intimate a nature, prosecuted as it was\namong associations of such jealously-guarded secrecy, that no one outside their\nranks could know anything of it, and those who shared in their initiation would\nsay nothing\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201c- and that everywhere\nhe was freely offered the hospitality of the temple or community in the place\nwhere he happened to be staying\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cVespasian, Titus, and\nNerva were all, prior to their elevation to the purple, friends and admirers of\nApollonius, while Nero and Domitian regarded the philosopher with dismay\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cEqually so he\njourneyed to Rome to meet Domitian face to face, and though he was put on trial\nand every effort made to prove him guilty of treasonable plotting with Nerva,\nhe could not be convicted of anything of a political nature. Nerva was a good\nman, he told the emperor, and no traitor. Not that Domitian had really any\nsuspicion that Apollonius was personally plotting against him; he cast him into\nprison solely in the hope that he might induce the philosopher to disclose the\nconfidences of Nerva and other prominent men who were objects of suspicion to\nhim, and who he imagined had consulted Apollonius on their chances of success.\nApollonius\u2019 business was not with politics, but with the \u201cprinces who asked him\nfor his advice on the subject of virtue\u201d (vi 43)\u201d</span><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cDamisa asked\nApollonius , before he sailed for India , if he knew the languages of several\nof the areas through which they had to pass. \u201cBut I understand them all, though\nI have learned none of them,\u201d answered Apollonius, in his usual enigmatical\nfashion \u201c<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cTwo thousand years ago\na great teacher of humanity appeared in the world. He was a philosopher, a\nsocial leader, a moral teacher, a religious reformer and a healer. From one end\nof the Roman empire to the other, wherever he went, divine honors were bestowed\non him -- by all, from slave to emperor. He was undoubtedly the greatest man of\nhis age; and his date of birth (4 B.C.) and period of activity coincided\nexactly with those of the Christian messiah, except that Apollonius\u2019s life of\nincessant labor in behalf of humanity extended for over a century\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cAlexandrian Library\nwith its 400,000 volumes, which was burnt to the ground by edict of Theodosius,\nwhen a Christian mob destroyed the Serapeum where the scrolls and manuscripts\nwere kept.&nbsp; . The librarians of the\nAlexandrian Library had secretly removed from it some of the most precious\nvolumes, which they carried eastward for safety\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cAmong the works which\nwere thus saved from the flames of the Alexandrian Library, the one which has\ncreated the most widespread and long-continued discussion was the \"Life of\nApollonius of Tyana,\" written by Flavius Philostratus at the beginning of\nthe third century A.D. As if by irony fate, this book - which of all books\nburnt in the Alexandrian Library, was one of the most dangerous - was preserved\ndown through the centuries, resisting all attempts to destroy it. The reason\nwhy this book was so much dreaded by the churchmen was because, while it made\nno mention whatsoever of the existence of Jesus or of Christianity, it\npresented Apollonius of Tyana as the universally acclaimed world teacher of the\nfirst century, reverenced from one end of the Roman Empire to the other, by\neveryone, from the lowest slave to the Emperor himself\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cFor Philostratus, in\nhis book described a character, born in the very year of the birth of Christ, who,\nin every respect, was the superior, of the Christian messiah Jesus Christ \u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In Taylor's\n\"Diegesis,\" [1829, Oaknam, England] we read:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"We have\ninvestigated the claims of every document possessing a plausible claim to be\ninvestigated which history has preserved of the transactions of the First\ncentury and not so much as a single passage, purporting to have been written at\nany time within the first hundred years, can be produced to show the existence\nof such a man as Jesus Christ or of such a set of men as could be accounted to\nbe his disciples.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"In the first\nchapter of Matthew the geneology of Jesus is given as the twenty-eighth\ngeneration from David down through Joseph to Christ. In the third chapter of\nLuke the same geneology is given as being the forty-third generation from\nChrist through Joseph to David. This is a very remarkable oversight on the part\nof the translators, for if there was anything they could agree on, it is in\nregard to the descent of Christ\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">J. M. Roberts, in his\n\"Antiquity Unveiled,\" &nbsp;writes:</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"All the\nChristians that ever lived or ever will live will find their ideal Jesus but a\nphantom -- a myth. They can chase it as a child would a butterfly through a\nmeadow on a summer's afternoon, and it will elude their grasp. The Christian\nJesus is nothing more than the Chrishna of the Hindus.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dr. Edmond B. Szekely,\nin his \"Origin of Christianity, writes:</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"There is not a\nword, or better, there is no longer a word in the works of Flavius Josephus\nabout the Messiah, the Christ crucified by Pontius Pilate, except for a crude\ninterpolation, quite obviously false...The silence of Josephus is not due to\ndisdain or studied neutrality.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<o:p>&nbsp;</o:p><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201c In his work,\n\"Orpheus the Fisher,\" Eisler shows that no representations can be\nfound among the catacomb inscriptions that depict Jesus, the cross or the\ncrucifixion. Instead, a Greek figure is represented as the leader of the sect,\na vegetarian and friend of animals, depicted either under the fig - of Orpheus\nplaying his lyre and surrounded by friendly animals, or as the Good Shepherd\n(Hermes) carrying a lamb around his neck. These representations obviously refer\nto Apollonius whose cardinal teachings consisted of vegetarianism and the\nabolition of animal sacrifices. Eisler's findings were further verified by\nLundy, who, in his \"Monumental Christianity,\" a work on early\nChristian archaeology, likewise reports the entire absence of any reference in\nthe catacomb inscriptions to Jesus or a crucified saviour, in whose place is\nfound the familiar Indian sage of Orpheus and the Good Shepherd, who are\nrepresented as friends of animals\u201d<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Below: Dark skinned Indian sage Orpeheus --tigers and peacocks are found in India.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-lg9byBB9AAg/VxEoHshzjuI/AAAAAAABHl8/f-ZX6cn84boQs5ixu075Nz1gMyb-KjBDACLcB/s1600/thracians-ordpheus-myth.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"446\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-lg9byBB9AAg/VxEoHshzjuI/AAAAAAABHl8/f-ZX6cn84boQs5ixu075Nz1gMyb-KjBDACLcB/s640/thracians-ordpheus-myth.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201c If we accept a few\npalpable forgeries, our knowledge of the life of Christ is based principally\nupon the accounts given in the Gospels... The gravest doubts exist as to the\nauthorship of the gospels of the New Testament. The Encyclopedia Brittannica\nacknowledges not only these doubts, but admits that there is no proof of any\nkind that the Gospels were written by the men whose names have been affixed to\nthem in more recent time.\"<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">J. M. Roberts wrote\nin&nbsp; \"Antiquity Unveiled,\":\n\"The world has the uncontrovertible testimony that Christianity is of\nspurious origin and the most consummate piece of plagiarism in human\nhistory.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cIn sharp contrast with\nthe scarcity, or rather the absence of information regarding Jesus, is the\nabundance of reliable historical data available concerning Apollonius of Tyana,\nwho, during the first century, enjoyed universal fame from one end of the Roman\nempire to the other, being honored by all. More than seventeen temples were\ndedicated to him in various parts of the empire. Nearly a dozen Roman Emperors\nheld him in awe and reverence. The Emperor Septimus Severus (A.D. 193-211\nerected a statue to him in his gallery of deities in the Pantheon</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">, while his son,\nEmperor Caracella, honored his memory with a chapel or monument.\u201d</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cLampridus, who lived\nin the third century, further informs us that the Emperor Alexander Severus (A.\nD. 222-235) placed a statue of Apollonius in his labarium side by side with one\nof Orpheus\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Another biography of\nApollonius was written by Soterichur of Oasis during the reign of Diocletian,\nand still another biography was written by Moeragenes.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cThough written in the\nearly part of the third century A.D., Philostratus's biography of Apollonius of\nTyana was not permitted to be publish.ed in Europe until the year 1501, when\nAldus printed the first Latin edition to appear in Europe. This was followed by\nan Italian and French translation, but it was not until 1680 that the first\nEnglish translation was made by Blount, an English Deist\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Blount's notes on the\nbook raised such an outcry that, in 1693, the book was condemned by the church\nand its further publication forbidden. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\" A century later\nBlount's notes were translated into French by the Encyclopedists. However, a\ncentury before Blount - Voltaire, Le Grand d'Aussy, Castillon and other French\nDeists wrote to the same effect, considering Apollonius as a far more authentic\nhistorical figure than Jesus, and fully his equal in every respect and as\nworthy of performing miracles if such were possible. Francis Bacon also spoke\nof Apollonius in the highest terms. \u201c<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Blount, however, had\ntranslated only the first two books of Philostratus's work (there were eight in\nall, the remaining six remaining unpublished); and it was not until 1809 that\nthe first complete English version was made by Edward Herwick. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;The popularity of Apollonius in ancient times\nstands in sharp contrast to his almost complete oblivion today.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mind you, he was born\nin the same mysterious manner in the same year when Jesus is supposed to have\nbeen born (the year 4 B.C.)</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Joseph John Campbell (\nborn 1904&nbsp; ) an American , writer and\nlecturer wrote&nbsp; \"A strange distinctive\nfigure, clad in white linen and not in garments wrought of skins; with feet\nunsandled and with locks unshorn; austere, reserved, and of meagre mien;\nwith-eyes cast upon the ground as was his manner, Apollonius of Tyana drew to\nhim with something of a saint's attraction all simple folk, and yet won as\nintimates the Emperors of Rome.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Through his love\nfor all life and swift appreciation of the beauty of the human form, he drew\nhigh to the sufferings of the body and became acquainted with the sufferings of\nthe soul. He sought to heal, or at least to soothe, some of the distresses,\nphysical and spiritual, of poor humanity; and to such a singular degree of\nskillfulness did he attain in the healing arts of his day, that even the sacred\noracles of Agaea and of Delphi pronounced him more than mortal, referred the\ndistempered body and the smitten soul to him, for relief, knowing that from his\nvery presence proceeded a peculiar virtue, a benign influence an almost\ntheurigic power.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"By years of\nsilence and contemplation, by extensive travel and by a continuous spiritual\nand worldly experience, he deepened to no minute measure, an originally,\npowerful. and intense personality, and so it was that at length he became the\nadmiration not only of all countries through which he passed, but of the whole\nRoman and Hellenic world. Cities sent envoys and embassies to him decreeing him\npublic favors; monarchs bestowed special dignities upon him, counting him\nworthy to be their counsellor; incense was burnt before his altars; and after\nhis death divine honours were paid to his images, which had been erected, with\ngreat enthusiasm, in all the temples of the gods. Nor did his fame evanesce.\nAll down the ages his name has carried in it something of a hurricane; for\nspeculative critics of both early and later days have thought to find in the\nlife of this exceptional character a parallel to the life of Christ, and to\nground an argument thereon, against the supernal claims of the Son of Man.\nHence for centuries even the name of Apollonius wag odious to Christians; for\nit seemed the very Gospel of the Son of Man was at stake; and Christian\napologists, on their part, in self-defense, were not lacking to attack fiercely\ntheir adversaries' champion, and to denounce him as little better than an\nimposter, a sorcerer and a magician; on this account they have generally failed\nto understand the man. They have lacked, at least in their combative approach\nto him, that sweet affection for signal worth, that gracious patience for\nnobleness, which is absolutely essential to comprehend a new or startling\ncharacter or mode of life.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"He had a\nZeus-like head, long beard and hair descending to his shoulders, bound with a\ndeep fillet. Damis describes Apollonius as ever mild, gentle and modest, and in\nthis manner, more like an Indian than a Greek, though, when witnessing some\nspecial enormity, he would burst out indignantly against it. His mood was often\npensive, and when not speaking he would remain for long with eyes cast down,\nplunged in deep thought. Though always stern with himself, he readily made\nexcuses for others. As an instance of this, the following may be cited: During\nNero's reign, when, on his way to Rome, Apollonius was warned that he and his\nfollowers would be in danger, of thirty-four companions who set out with him,\nonly eight remained staunch enough to brave the threatened peril; while\npraising the courage of those few who remained with him, he refused to blame as\ncowards the many who had fled.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"All his life long\nhis advice and help were constantly sought by cities, temples and rulers\neverywhere, and were freely given without reward. He journeyed over the known\nworld from the Atlantic ocean to the Ganges river, and south to the cataracts\nof the Nile, acquiring and imparting wisdom. In middle age, when his travels\nwere not half completed, he told his disciples that he had already seen more of\nthe earth's surface than any other man had ever done. During his long and\nlaborious life he wrought many wonders, and many men regarded him as an incarnate\ndivinity. The kings of Persia and of India vied with each other to do him\nhonor.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hierocles of Alexandria\nactive around AD 430. He studied under Plutarch he never mentions Christianity\nin his works<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hierocles wrote a\ntreatise in which he maintained that Apollonius was a fat far higher type than\nthe Jesus Christ of the Gospels. the Catholic opponents of Apollonius invented\nthe most ridiculous lies to belittle his character.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Plutarch of Athens was\na Greek philosopher and Neoplatonist who taught at Athens Plutarch is the\nperson who reestablished Plato's Academy Platonic Academy The Academy&nbsp; was founded by Plato (428 BC \u2013 348 BC who had\nlearnt in Kodungallur University like Pythagoras ) in Athens.&nbsp;&nbsp; Aristotle (384 BC \u2013 322 BC) studied there\nfor twenty years (367 BC \u2013 347 BC) before founding his own school, the Lyceum.\nThe Platonic Academy has been cited by historians as the first higher learning\ninstitution in the Western world and was full of book on Indian wisdom it\ncontained a sacred grove of olive trees dedicated to Athena, the goddess of\nwisdom, -same as Saraswati.&nbsp;&nbsp; The site of\nthe Academy is located near Colonus, approximately, 1 km north of Athens'\nDipylon gates.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cApollonius of Tyna's &nbsp;knowledge of\nlanguages was universal. From one end of the Roman Empire to the other he\ntraveled as a teacher and healer, to whom the sick flocked wherever he went. He\nwas also a social reformer and revolutionist, who fearlessly opposed tyrants\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Reville, a Catholic\nwriter, in his book on Apollonius of Tyana, admits, \" The story of Jesus was\nonly the offering of an obscure people; his shallow doctrine was but the\nrefinement of a paltry local tradition; his life, of which little is known the\ngreat majority of his contemporaries, was extremely short. He soon fell victim\nto the attacks of two or three priests, a petty king, and a prosecutor, and a\nfew remarkable progidies alone distinguished him from a crowd of other\nexistences which had nothing whatever to do with the destinies of humanity.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Apollonius, on\nthe contrary, a Greek by birth, had stored his vast intellect with the\nreligious doctrines of the whole world, from India to Cordoba Spain; his life\nextended. over a century. Like a luminous meteor he traversed the universe, in\nconstant intercourse with kings and the powerful ones of the earth, who\nvenerate and fear him, and if he ever meets with opposition, he triumphs over\nit majestically, always stronger than his tyrants, never subject to\nhumiliation, never brought into contact with public executioners.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Danile M tredwell\nTredwell,( 1826-1921 )&nbsp; in his\n\"Sketch of the Life of Apollonius of Tyana,\" writes as follows:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"That Apollonius\nwas a great and good man can hardly be questioned; the tribute paid him by\nTitus, Vespasian and Aurelius is a guarantee. Even among those of the present\nday most willing to detract from his character many are forced to admit that a\ncertain pure and true morality pervades the whole of his system of teaching.\nThere is a well- established theory in it, that virtue and true piety is the\nonly foundation of happiness.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Apollonius was\nchaste and temperate; he was actuated by a noble desire to know and the still\nnobler desire to communicate his knowledge to mankind. He was ingenious,\nlearned and original in his language. No man ever lived who utterly rejected\nall vulgar artifice for producing effect upon men; no majestical pomp of words\ncharacterised his teachings. And he was ready at all times and in all places to\nimpart good instruction; and from all testimony of him no man was more\nemphatically an apostle of peace. It is difficult, indeed, to overcome the\ncommon-sense conclusion that Apollonius, whom Philostratus has placed before\nus, is a real man, a corporeity, and not a spirit; he walks the earth, eats,\ndrinks and sleeps like other men, loves and hates as experience teaches us is\nnatural for man. He is an observer of natural phenomena, compares and\nspeculates, adores nature, birds, animals, trees, flowers and is not destitute\nof humor, although of great gravity and dignity. Everywhere in nature and art,\nwith the Brahmans of India, he found something to admire.\"</span><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cTowards the end of the\nthird century, just previous to the formation of the church, the struggle\nbetween the Pythagorean supporters of Apollonius and his opponents, who later\norganized the Roman Catholic Church at Nicea, reached its last and bitter\nstages . At this time there were temples and shrines all over Asia Minor\ndedicated to Apollonius and his work, but there were none , not even one , to\nJesus Christ, for he was unknown since he did not exist\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cIn the place of the\naugust Apollonius, whose fame was world wide during the first three centuries,\nand who was revered in all centers of learning as the wisest of men, his\nopponents endeavored to set up an uneducated youth named Jeus of only local\nsignificance, who was known only to a few illiterate fishermen in his vicinity,\nand whose short period of activity (3 years) and his short life (33 years)\nprecluded his achieving what Apollonius with his century of incessant activity\nhad accomplished. While Jesus spent his life in Galilee among the common\npeople, Apollonius traveled from one end of the world to the other, studying\nthe wisdom of the greatest minds that could be found -- the Brahmans of the\nHimalayas, the Gymnosophist philosophers of Egypt, and Druids of Gaul, etc.\u201d</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to Tredwell,\nApollonius travelled more extensively than any man of his age. \"That he\nwas a man of no mean account,\" Tredwell adds, \"is evident from his\nletters addressed to kings, rulers, philosophers societies and the first men of\nhis time, still extant, reserved in the works of Philostratus and Cujacius. He\ntraveled among the Magi and was everywhere the more honored on account of his\nmodesty and virtues; giving always wise and prudent counsel, and rarely\ndisputing with anyone. The prayer which he was accustomed to offer up to the\ngods is admirable. \"O, ye immortal gods, grant us whatever you shall judge\nit fit and proper to bestow, and of which we may not be undeserving.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For many centuries\nafter his passing, a halo of sanctity was thrown around his head, and he was\nworshipped as a god in many parts of the world. The Tyanaeans elevated Apollonius\nto the position of a demigod, and the Roman emperors approved his apotheosis.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ammonianus Marcellinus\nranked Apollonius among the most eminent men, and claimed that he prophesied by\nsupernatural aid of a genius. Apollonius never encouraged the propagation of\nhis divine nature.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Concerning Apollonius's\nuniversal renown during the first century, W.B. Wallace writes: \"His noble\ncountenance, his winning presence, his pure doctrine, his unsullied life, his\nardent advocacy of the immortality of the soul, as well as his miracles - led\nmen to believe, wherever he went, that he was more than mortal. He consorted\nand corresponded with the mighty ones of the earth. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">J.A. Froude writes:\nAccording to Philostratus he was a heathen saviour, who claimed a commission\nfrom heaven to teach a pure and reformed religion, and in attestation of his\nauthority went about healing the sick, curing the blind, raising the dying men\nto life, casting out demons, stilling tempests, and prophesying future events -\nwhich came afterwards to pass.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Phillimore wrote \u201c\nApollonius was himself an object of worship -- because of his sanctity, wisdom,\nbeauty, etc. - wherever he went.&nbsp; His\nmagic powers, which seem to have been considerable, procured for local piety his\nrecognition as an object of cultus in his Cappadocian birth-place,\" that\nApollonius's \"temle\" whose adherents were known as\n\"Apolloniei\" survived for some centuries after his death, and\nconstituted the origin of what, after the Council of Nicea, was later\ntransformed into he Christian Church\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vopiscus wrote in\nLatint, he says, \"his deeds and words may be on the tongues of all, for as\nyet the only accounts are in Greek.&nbsp; For\nwho among men,\" he adds, \"was more holy, more worthy of reverence, more\nvenerable and more god-like than he?\"&nbsp;\nHe it was who gave life to the dead. He it was who did and said so many\nthings beyond the power of men.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Leo, the chancellor of\na Frankish king at Toulouse, wrote:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Throw aside your\nendless labors and steal a respite from the burdens and bustle of the Court, so\nthat you may really study this long-expected volume as it deserves. When once\nabsorbed in it, you will wander with our Tyanean over Caucasus and Indus, to\nBrahmans of India and the naked philosophers of Nubia. It describes the life of\nvery much such a man as you are, with due respect to your Catholic faith.\nCourted by sovereigns, but never courting them; eager For knowledge; aloof from\nmoney-getting; fasting at feasts; linen-clad among wearers of purple; rebuking\nluxury; self-contained; plain-spoken; shock-headed in the midst of perfumed\nkings, who themselves were reeking with myrrh and malo-bathrum and polished\nwith pumice-stone; taking from the flocks nothing to eat or to wear; and\nnotwithstanding all these peculiarities not distrusted but honored wherever he\nwent throughout the world, and although royal treasures were placed at his\ndisposal, accepted from them merely those gifts to his friends which it suited\nhim better to bestow than to receive. In short, if we measure and weigh\nrealities, no philosopher's biography equal to this has ever appeared in the\ntimes of our ancestors; so far as I know; and I am certain that in my times it\nfinds a worthy reader in you.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cIt was not until\nHierocles in the beginning of the fourth century boldly charged upon the\nChristian priesthood their plagiarism of the teachings and works of Apollonius,\nthat the latter found it necessary to set every means at work that could in any\nway help to conceal the great truth that Hierocles proclaimed with such\nportentious force. It was true that no one knows exactly what it was that\nHierocles wrote, for Eusebius, who took upon himself the task of destroying the\ntestimony of Hierocles, took precious good care to destroy the work of his\nformidable opponent, and give his own version of the matter instead.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hierocles is most\nfamous for his Elements of Ethics, parts of which (about 300 lines) were\nuncovered in the form of a papyrus as recently as 1901.&nbsp; We also have other fragments from Hierocles,\nthrough the writings of Stobaeus<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Egyptian epic poet of\nthe last decade of the third century, Nichomachus, and Tascius Victorianus all\npaid glowing tributes to Apollonius,<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Damisa wrote Apollonius\nsaid to him \"You need not wonder at my knowing all human languages; for,\nto tell you the truth, I also understand all the secrets of human\nsilence.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">A lot\nof Essenes and the Nazarenes of Qumran, fled to Antioch when their Dead Sea\nexistence was faced with destruction , and they were to be burnt alive , as\nordered by the Catholic church.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">From there they came to Muziris in batches by\nship.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;Kerala\nspice merchants and diamond traders took them in on their ships in the ballast\nvoyage to Muziris . &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">This is how the\nKerala NASRANIS, KNANAYAS AND ACHAYANS &nbsp;reached Kerala from Antioch. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">They are pagan Hindus with a glorious and\nenviable and NOT bullshit Jews or fake Christians . &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">During\nthe white invaders rule these misled people , converted to Christianity and let\nBharatmata down. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Continue being Christians\nof Jews as your heart says, but do NOT be traitors henceforth. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">One day I will put a post on the Kerala Jews\nand Christians who were desh drohis .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The writers of the\nancient dead sea scrolls were alive with fervour for their vital mission and\nshining with love for their Teacher from God. &nbsp;They recorded their times in a uniquely poetic\nvoice and left for us a priceless store.&nbsp;\n&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Truths buried for two\nmillenniums should NOT be fudged by immoral Jew and Christian historians .&nbsp;&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Today the world knows\nyou foul and dark history \u2013 &nbsp;praising yourselves\n&nbsp;( where there is ABSOLUTELY nothing to\nfeel proud about ) and injecting poison into ANCIENT HINDUISM &nbsp;to make pagans and Hindus&nbsp; self loathing.. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">All this wont work any more.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b>Jews and Christians\noften point to these scrolls as evidence for the integrity of the Old Testament\ntext.&nbsp;</b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">GREEDY Jews now kicked\nthe Vatican on their collective balls and cry \u201c&nbsp;\nThe Dead Sea Scrolls are not in any way \u201cChristian records;\u201d they are\nJewish writings from a Jewish religious sect, most of which predate the time of\nChrist (and thus Christianity) by several decades, and in some cases one or two\ncenturies. These scrolls contain no \u201cgospels.\u201d &nbsp;&nbsp;In fact, Jesus of Nazareth is never even\nmentioned in the Dead Sea Scrolls.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>BALLS &nbsp;!</b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">THESE SCROLLS\nHAVE NOTHING TO DO WITH JEWS.&nbsp; THE WORD\nJEW IS NOT MENTIONED ANYWHERE .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">TEE HEEE !<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">THE CATHOLIC AND JEW\nHISTORIANS CRY--The Dead Sea Scrolls are ancient manuscripts known by some as\n\"the greatest manuscript discovery of modern times.\" They include\nbooks of the Torah (which forms the Christian Old Testament) and non-Biblical\ntexts dating from 100 BC to AD 68. The scrolls are records of events created\nand recorded by scribes of the day. They are a thousand years older than the\noldest Hebrew {Masoretic} text of the Torah. The English version of the Old\nTestament is based on this version of the Torah. The scrolls are believed to\nhave been written during one of the most important periods of the Jewish\npeople, on the eve of Christianity. They provide an enormously valuable\nresource for the study of Biblical texts and the people who wrote them, as well\nas, of the Jewish history during the 4th century BC. The scrolls shed new light\non the foundations of Christianity and the influence of Judaism on the\nChristian faith.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>BALLS AGAIN !!</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The Govt of Israel has taken ownership of the\ndead sea scrools .&nbsp; These scrolls then\nmade their way to the U.S. and finally were bought for the Israeli government\nfor 250, 000 USD <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-CUQRr-x6wZM/VxIIWtHa3RI/AAAAAAABHm8/HVnLU6mrmwoGD-RD0NK7pF40yxwWIbp2wCLcB/s1600/28ED5AA200000578-3089240-image-ah-8_1432201214208.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"508\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-CUQRr-x6wZM/VxIIWtHa3RI/AAAAAAABHm8/HVnLU6mrmwoGD-RD0NK7pF40yxwWIbp2wCLcB/s640/28ED5AA200000578-3089240-image-ah-8_1432201214208.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">He would\nspeak at the Agora ( large speech pavilion ) where his voice would be\namplified. After Apollonius dies his state was in the Agora.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">ISIS\nissued a statement that it did not intend to demolish the buildings at\nPalmyra's World Heritage Site, but stated that it would destroy any artifact it\ndeemed &nbsp;\"pagan\"<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-2VIXipc96ts/VxIHpE8zW-I/AAAAAAABHmw/MmhhbTAW-L40nz2StAMcnQymYpZ8vfp5gCLcB/s1600/2BE7CD2300000578-3218714-The_temple_of_Baal_Shamin_ifrs_destroyed_by_ISIS_It_has_been_sugge-a-5_1441209698035.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Baal\nis Shiva&nbsp; ( Kabaaleshar )<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-pKD5bpKn6e0/VxIHDxoV46I/AAAAAAABHmo/E2-pEfr32mkrXnMSXlMqRimKuqEqMXm-QCLcB/s1600/bafal.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"320\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-pKD5bpKn6e0/VxIHDxoV46I/AAAAAAABHmo/E2-pEfr32mkrXnMSXlMqRimKuqEqMXm-QCLcB/s320/bafal.jpg\" width=\"165\" /></a></div>\n<br />\nBelow : Spice ladedn ships of the King of Calicut from Muziris used to unload on to camel caravans ( at Salala / Aden ) who watered their camels and registered at customs outposts ( oasis ) at Mecca, Peta and BOSRA . <br />\n<br />\nApollonius spoke often at BOSRA.to jam packed galleries -- the voice used to carry clear. In his young days Apollonius observed total silence VRAT for 5 long years . When he finally decided to speak, people were stunned.<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-GyCKhNkx81I/VxIQtigWLdI/AAAAAAABHn0/doEQpZfFLi01_8I98hmEJlJX75xKJUM-ACLcB/s1600/fad19359acf84cd5a12023ca482ds40fdef5fad41c.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-z1wTocyY8yo/VxIRieywMGI/AAAAAAABHn8/JRdgxCFujvo7s1_eqW1wA08x0NSAi7ucgCLcB/s1600/unesco-ancient-cirty-of-bosra-n1-syria-syria%252B1152_12928033672-tpfil02aw-27942.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-z1wTocyY8yo/VxIRieywMGI/AAAAAAABHn8/JRdgxCFujvo7s1_eqW1wA08x0NSAi7ucgCLcB/s1600/unesco-ancient-cirty-of-bosra-n1-syria-syria%252B1152_12928033672-tpfil02aw-27942.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Apollonius used to\nspeak in the amphitheatre of Bosra, once the capital of the Roman province of\nArabia, an important oasis watering hole stopover on the ancient spice caravan\nroute from Mecca to Damascus.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-80VurVAv18w/VxIShMOWy3I/AAAAAAABHoI/N8YiHzjbstgEfgPSYCuPeWdM0o9Fui39QCLcB/s1600/146b057841.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"424\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-80VurVAv18w/VxIShMOWy3I/AAAAAAABHoI/N8YiHzjbstgEfgPSYCuPeWdM0o9Fui39QCLcB/s640/146b057841.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Every pagan statue of the temple of Bosra has\nbeen smashed up by Christians and Muslims.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Below: The temple tank as BOSRA.</span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7C8bYtfzJfg/VxITLV42mZI/AAAAAAABHoQ/ZomOdW8OuDEKe1inIriYVNydCo4q6rHLgCLcB/s1600/cistern-dug-by-the-romrans-after-their-conquest-of-the-city-in-106-BKR1WM.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"470\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7C8bYtfzJfg/VxITLV42mZI/AAAAAAABHoQ/ZomOdW8OuDEKe1inIriYVNydCo4q6rHLgCLcB/s640/cistern-dug-by-the-romrans-after-their-conquest-of-the-city-in-106-BKR1WM.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">HEBREW WAS REVIVED IN THE END OF 19<sup>TH</sup>\n&nbsp;CENTURY BY ROTHSCHILD , TO CLAIM AND USURP\nTHE LAND OF PALESTINE .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The revival process of the Hebrew language\ntook place in Europe &nbsp;through which the\nlanguage's usage changed from the liturgical language language of ancient Judaism\nto a spoken and written language used for modern life in Israel.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The revival of Hebrew was a master plan by\nZionist Jews in conjunction with carve out Israel policy.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The characteristics of spoken Hebrew only\nbegan to seep into literature in the 1940s, and only in the 1990s did spoken\nHebrew start widely appearing in novels<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Rothschild employee Eliezer Ben-Yehuda\n(1858\u20131922) is the \"reviver of the Hebrew language\" .&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Rothschild made him spend four years in\nParis and arrange to import a Jew from Jerusalem who was fluent in spoken Hebrew . &nbsp;They met in Rothschild's hospital in Paris.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Eliezer Ben-Yehuda raised the first modern\nHebrew-speaking child, his first son &nbsp;Ben-Zion Ben-Yehuda (Itamar Ben-Avi)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Check out the advance planning of Jew\nRothschild.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">He then sent Eliezer Ben-Yehuda to Palestine\nto lay the ground work of the white skinned Jew\u2019s claim for Palestine. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">He made a Rothschild funded &nbsp;Hebrew dictionary Milon Halashon Ha\u2019ivrit\nha\u2019yshana vehakhadasha borrowing humongous amount of foreign words, slightly\naltering them, &nbsp;to make the liturgical rustic\nlanguage modern enough to dabble in science and math. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">While in USA , in search for words for his\ndictionary , he was a house guest of Rothschild\u2019s agent Jew &nbsp;Whorthiem in New York. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Rothschild got his access to American\nlibraries, being the only man ever to be given a room to do research at the New\nYork public library on 42 street and Fifth Avenue. From this you can see\nRothschild\u2019s clout with the President of USA.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">After his death in 1922, his second wife Hemda\n( sister of his first wife ) and his son Ehud, finished his work.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Eliezer Ben-Yehuda never saw the creation of\nthe State of Israel. He passed away only one month after the British\nauthorities declared Hebrew to be the official language of the Jews of\nPalestine<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Rothschild got him buried with great honours on\nthe Mount of Olives in Jerusalem ( 1922 ) though this man\u2019s ancestors (\nPerelman ) were not from Palestine.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">&nbsp;</span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-aSnWTIO2h_s/VxI3r_u4f7I/AAAAAAABHog/PNcAephKyL4xzHcr5AkqLyQrDM_Hcdq4gCLcB/s1600/Eliezer-Ben-Yehuda-grave-sitde-Mount-of-olives-Jerusalem-2010.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em;
